text: Cool, thank you. Tēnā koutou katoa. For those who don't know me, ko Debbie LaSalle is taku rangoa. So yeah, I've been working at Waipā District Council for a year now. So I was born in Auckland and moved to the mighty Waikato 20 years ago, where I have had my three children and here is where I have remained. So yeah, it's lovely to be here. I haven't met all of you in person, but I hope to do so. That would be great.  So just here to talk to you today about COVID-19. So as an organisation, council is considering how we will approach recovery from this quite remarkable event, which has impacted all of our lives. So initially we've been monitoring the economic data and just keeping a close eye on the economic productions for the district.  In Waipā we're a little bit better off than other districts because our economy is based quite predominantly on the farming sector, which hasn't been hit as hard as some of the other sectors. We are still expecting unemployment to rise though and our hospitality industry has taken quite a big hit. Over the next 12 months we're expecting that house prices will drop and both residential and non-residential construction will drop as well.  So we've also started meeting with our local community and that includes iwi authorities in Hapū, just to talk to people about what they're experiencing, what they have experienced and also just to ask them what their priorities are in terms of recovery. So we've met with quite a few of the social sector, so the kind of  a lot of the service providers in Te Aumaru and Cambridge as well and we're just sort of collecting up things in terms of what's sort of happening on the ground for people so quite a bit of that is indicating that there are still redundancies to come so we're expecting that the worst hasn't hit us yet so that's just something that we need to continue to monitor ongoing  I think another common theme that has come through from those meetings is that there is some real concern about how we will meet the needs in our communities, that our social services are stretched already, some concern about the lack of philanthropic funding, given that the gaming trusts are not going to be operational for a while, they haven't been collecting any income during lockdown, so that will probably have quite a significant impact.  especially on our non-governmental organisation sort of sector, our charitable kind of sector. A lot of talk about building resilience and self-sustainability and wanting to help people to get out of the situation and then not be put back into a similar vulnerable situation again. So things like community gardens,  teaching people even how to cook, how to sew, financial literacy, so how to work on a low income. All of that have been kind of recurrent things which people have discussed. So the response to COVID-19 has been a civil defence response, so the welfare  has been led through our organisation and led by our civil defence team. But pretty early on, central government indicated that recovery probably wouldn't be led by civil defence. And that's because this isn't the kind of usual civil defence emergency that you would typically see. So in most civil defence emergencies, it's a short, sharp hit. It's over pretty quickly and then you transition onto recovery.  Whereas with COVID-19, we had a very long rolling response and the impacts of that are still going to be felt probably for many months to come. It's significantly more complex than a standard civil defence emergency. So central government have indicated that they think the best approach to leading recovery is through the standard ministerial offices.  So the current thinking is, or the language that they are using, is locally led, centrally enabled, which means that local government has always had responsibility for leading recovery in local communities, but they are indicating that they are really expecting local government to collaborate with one another, but also really work with our local communities to  assist the community to recover from this. So as an organisation we've set up an internal project group and we've set some initial strategic priorities and those are based on the information that we have collected from communities and from the data that we've had to date. We will continue to refine those priorities as more information becomes available and  You'll see from my report that staff are proposing that we create two new roles and those roles will really be to work on the ground out in communities to assist with recovery activities. So we're saying that those people would be quite hands on. This obviously is going to go  needs to be approved by council the week after next. So it hasn't been formally approved yet, but that's sort of one of our proposed approaches. And I'm thinking that we need to take a reasonably flexible and agile approach to this, given that we don't know yet just exactly how this is going to pan out. Yeah, but I'm happy to take any questions. Greg Morgan Thanks, Debbie.
speaker: debbielascelle

text: Look, this was a project that was started before my time at Council. I started a year ago. This started back in 2015 when Council, following the Ngāti Koriki-Kahakura settlement, initiated the review and so they followed the Reserves Act process of doing that first step where you say we're going to review the plan and you seek initial submissions on that  there was a bit of a gap because of resourcing and capacity and then we've picked it up and worked with Becca from last year and with the reference group which was made up of Poto Davies, Linda Te Aho and Thelma Reti and took those submissions into consideration to develop the draft plan and  This is what was gifted to us from the reference group and is included in the plan here so I'll let you read that.  So in preparing it, we spoke to a number of stakeholders, obviously the mana whenua, the regional council, the Department of Conservation, and we went to the Maungatautari Reserve Committee several times with the draft plan. I thought it'd just be useful just to, most of you will know the maunga well, but just to indicate with these couple of maps,  Just the area. So in here, the map shows and read the pest proof fence. The southern and northern enclosure and the tracks across the maunga. The management plan itself actually only covers the scenic reserve land. So that's about three quarters of the land that's included within the pest proof fence.  And the management plan is an important document to guide all those other plans that will govern the day-to-day management of the maunga. So it's influenced by a number of pieces of legislation and strategies and policies, including the iwi environment plans. And then as I said, it influences a number of other plans. The vision  was worked through and largely drafted and put forward by the reference group, and I think it's fantastic. I think that if we look at the big changes from the current management plan, which was adopted in 2005, to this draft management plan, which we're out for consultation on at the moment, is we've got, tried to make it a document that really speaks to the  the significance of the maunga to mana whenua, but to all of us, the fact that it is this taonga toko iho and to try and really convey some of those messages to get the hearts and minds of people to understand the importance of the maunga and therefore also, I guess, hopefully then understand the rationale for the policies and the framework that guides the day-to-day management of the maunga.  This is a new part that the old management plan didn't have. We've got principles that are to guide all decisions in relation to the maunga and they were developed obviously in partnership with the reference group and include things like wairuatanga, kaitiakitanga, manaakitanga, mahi nga tahi. So I think principles that will speak to everyone.  The management plan then goes into having a number of sections covering off the objectives and policies. And some of those are quite similar to what's in the existing management plan. But I think there is a real focus on the partnership component with mana whenua, with volunteers, with other stakeholders.  is probably one of the things that's really come through in this plan. So the plan we released last Monday for public consultation, under the Reserves Act, you're required to have a two-month period. We've extended that to 10 weeks to take into account the impacts of COVID and give people more time.  We have put public notices into all the local newspapers, doing quite a strong push through social media. We've sent letters out to adjoining landowners, mana whenua, key stakeholders, and have made the plans available at the libraries and council offices. There's an online survey form which we're encouraging people to provide their submission through.  but we're also very happy to receive written submissions either by way of email or hand delivery or by post. At SPMP, we sought a resolution to appoint two independent hearing commissioners to hear and recommend back to council. So those independent commissioners haven't been found yet. Now, I was asked to speak to Waikato, Waikato Tainui, but also took the opportunity to revisit and have broader conversations with other, with other iwi authorities and runanga, etc. And so we've covered off a wide base of iwi  Some discussions are yet to still happen, but generally this is the trend that we've found is that everyone spoken to thus far agrees that the council should adopt a standard. Now the standard isn't just about macros. So that is the likes of Taumaroa, Paraone Gloyne, spoke also with Harry Midwood. Who else have we spoken with? A range of people. Aunty Rovina has spoken with  Rāhui Papa, and Rāhui, to his credit, also stated that the way forward is with the provision by Te Taura Whiri Te Reo Māori, the Māori Language Commission. Interesting enough for him, it was a matter of whakapapa, that the government, central government, created or enabled the Māori Language Commission, and therefore,  It only makes sense that the uri or the local councils, which are seen in the whakapapa as the children of central government, that what's good for the government, what's good for the parent is also good for the children. Both are allowed for certainly in their internal documents and signage etc. Waikato tend to use the double vowel but they also noted in the document and its recommendations  which are the standard now for Waikato-Tainui, that should signage, etc. not allow for the length of a name because of the double vowel, then they revert back to the macron. Now this gets quite technical, so I will try and simplify things as much as I can so you can follow what I'm saying. So if I step back a little bit from the information that you can see, and that's in the report, what we have in our district plan is areas that we've zoned deferred zones. So these zones show  The areas that we've identified through our growth strategy that we want to take from rural zone to some sort of residential or large lot zone or an industrial or commercial zone. So the areas that we've been out, we've talked to the community, it's come through that growth strategy process. And our way of showing them in the district plan is to show them as deferred zones.  Now that we've got them in our district plan so you can see where they are, there is some more steps that people have to take to then subdivide and develop on that land. So they first have to get what we call a structure plan approved, and that's a very high-level plan that sets out where the roads and infrastructure goes, if there's going to be just all residential zone or if there's going to be a block of commercial somewhere in the mix, that kind of thing.  So they go through the structure plan process, which is a resource consent process, which we come through, and I often see those, and I think I've seen a couple of you at those meetings to talk through some of those structure plan applications. Once they've got consent for that structure plan, the next step is to uplift the deferred zone. So this is where we take a resolution to the council and say, please, can we  we take it from deferred zone and call it its live zone. So most of our growth cells are going into residential zones, but there are some that we uplift that go into commercial or industrial zones. After that second step, then the developers are required to lodge the subdivision consents, and that's when the real detailed design comes through in that subdivision. So that's how the current plan works for this process. Recently,  Council have become aware of some case law about best practice for how these processes should work. And as a result of that case law, we need to just make some slight tweaks to our district plan to make sure we're still doing the best practice process to enable development of these areas. Next slide, please, Anne. And so what we've done here is  and to try and create our best practice process, I've come up with some options of what we could do. So they're very technical, and all the detail is in your report in front of you. But very simply, we have the options of doing nothing. So that's basically keeping the status quo. I don't think our lawyers will like this option, so we do need to  Although it's an option, it's probably not what we call a realistic option to consider. An option that we could use is something called incorporation by reference. So the Resource Management Act has a very big schedule at the back, which tells you all this very technical information. But very simply, there's a clause in there that allows you to reference a document in your district plan.  and we could use that process as an option to include structure plan in the district plan. It would mean that we basically end up with a list that sits separate from the district plan, and that list would tell people when zones were live or not. A third option we have is just to be quite bold and just take all the deferred zones out completely. This would be probably one of the more extreme  options, but there are a lot of district plans around that don't use a deferred zone as an option. So what those district plans do instead is they basically show the areas as like a rural zone. And if you wanted to develop in that space, you would have to go through a full plan change process, which can be quite time consuming and cost consuming.  The fourth option, option four, is to uplift the deferred zones in our pre-2035 growth cells. So these are the cells that we've identified through our growth strategy as needing to go before 2035 to meet our requirements under some of the government legislation about providing for growth. So this would enable those  areas to just go straight to that third step I talked about earlier and just lodge those subdivision consents. Option five is a little bit different. It's an idea I had that we would basically keep doing the process that we have been doing, but once a year or every two years, council would do a little mock-up plan change to basically tidy up any areas that have been already through those consent processes.  This option means a regular commitment from council, but the positive I could see with this option is that everyone, if you made it a regular timing, everyone would know and be able to work to that timing, which I could see being quite beneficial for some developers. If they know it's coming, they can get the A into G and make sure that they've got all their consents sorted before we do our mop-up plan change to make the district plan reflect the zone that they need.  And the last option there, option six, is we could remove the process that we have in our district plan for getting a structured plan approved via resource consent. So again, this is a process that a lot of other councils don't use, but we identified through the district plan review as an enabling sort of process, but it is one we could look at taking out to make things a bit simpler, and this would  mean that if people wanted to proceed with a structure plan, they would have to go back to that schedule one resource management process of doing a full plan change, which, like I said earlier, can be time consuming and cost consuming. So that's my very brief summary of those options. I'm happy to take questions because it's obviously very technical, and I apologize if I've used way too much planning jargon, as I know planners like to.  So no questions are dumb questions, so happy to take any.

So we have commenced having a look at some of these rules and  Like Hayley, we've got a couple of options, and I'll just run through them really briefly. So one is the status quo, and that would mean leaving everything as it is, everybody having to apply for a consent, especially in Cambridge North, because very few houses there meet the requirements or the permitted standard in the district plan. So they always have to apply for a resource consent.  So it's not ideal because it makes it very hard for the plan to administer if we just leave it the same as it is. So we could look at changing the definitions, which would tidy things up. And some of the rules are a bit poorly worded and could be changed. So that's one that could sort of easily be achieved. Another option is to change the threshold within the performance standards for the permitted activity.  So in most of the residential zone in the district, you need 40% of the site to have permeable surfaces, as in gardens, lawns, that sort of thing. In the Cambridge North area, they're required to have 55%, which is significantly higher. So what we would like to do is get an engineer to review the original data as to why we came up with that.  threshold in the first place, and to see if it's still relevant, bearing in mind that Cambridge North has reasonably developed already, and it may be that it's not necessary to change it, there's not enough evidence to change it. And another way to change things is to change the activity status. So at the moment, in Cambridge North, if somebody is over the 55%,  as in their house is too big for the site or they want to put in a swimming pool or a patio and it makes it over the 55, they need to apply for a discretionary resource consent. So that's quite a high bar to get over and it's a reasonably expensive exercise because they have to, not only do they have to get an engineer to design their stormwater disposal, they then have to apply for a consent to council, which is,  a deposit of a couple of thousand dollars. If we change the activity status, as in made it not so difficult to pass, we could potentially keep giving them their resource consents, but it wouldn't cost the individual home builder as much money. So that's something else that we need to look into in terms of the finance team will probably give us some assistance as to how much does it actually cost  How much does that add to the whole building project? Could we do it a different way? Next please, Sam. Does anybody have any questions about permeable surfaces before we move on to the next plan change?

text: Tēnā koutou, koutou, koutou. Good afternoon, everybody. Good afternoon, Your Worship and iwi, consultative committee members. Hopefully you can hear me all right. I don't have my earphones on here today. This is just an update on the civil defence COVID-19 Western Waikato emergency response. So a national state of emergency was declared on the 25th of March 2020, a response to the COVID-19  emergency event. So that was to support the activities of the health sector, particularly the Ministry of Health, the District Health Board. So the Western Waikato Emergency Operations Centre, the EOC, that was established in the Waipara District Council offices in Te Amutu. Now that was an EOC that was part of four EOCs that were established in the Waikato area and supported by the group, the GECC, at the Hamilton office.  The Western Waikato EOC that represented Waipa, Waitrohola and Waitomo on their shared service arrangements. I thought that went really, really well. The EOC consisted of staff from all three councils. Its primary purpose was to provide for the non-health needs of the communities within the Waipa, Waitrohola and Waitomo districts. So in the report, we've identified the key priorities of the EOC.  But in particular, the priority was about really, in practical terms, coordinating and enabling the social and welfare services across our communities. So including establishing and operating the CDM 0800 number to manage a significant surge in the requests that our normal social services couldn't handle. We were directly involved with the provision of household goods and services, temporary accommodation,  food assistance to individuals, families, and whānau. So those were the principal activities that the CDM group were involved with. The other priorities are identified there in section three of the report. So I talked a little bit about public information management. We issued almost daily media releases reminding the community of the R800 number, the food banks, just reinforcing that the messages of the various levels of government  requirements at the time. There's a section there about the vulnerable groups. So an important part of the local response was supporting the welfare of most of the vulnerable people in our communities. And that was represented from several iwi groups within our three districts. We're very instrumental in reaching out and coordinating assistance for the people that needed our support the most.  I think it would be fair to say that we were a bit slow off the mark initially with our EOC to get the established iwi connections by our various groups. But once with the work particularly of Shane Taruku to assist in getting the right representatives inputting into the EOC and there are a number that came through and inputted into  the OCs versus Zoom briefings that we had in the morning and afternoon. And once we could understand and they could understand what was going on on a daily basis, I think the response in terms of the area was far greater. So that was just, I guess, an evolving situation. And I think in the end, it was working very well.  We identified the key people there from the various trust boards. The food banks there, so just going through the further on the report. So as I say, some of the key things was establishing the close relationship with the local food banks, the various marae as well. There was a tremendous number of food parcels that was distributed throughout our region. We identified there that the various food  banks, the marae, particularly the Maniapoto Marae Trust Board where Mekatu Marae was involved as a distribution centre for eight marae. And I think that worked really reasonably well. And it wasn't just food that was going out to them, there was firewood, blankets, all the other important things associated with the welfare needs of our communities. We also helped and supported the Waikato Tainui  Kaipak distribution centers in both Te Kiki and Cambridge. So we supported with a list of logistical support and security associated with that. And I think that was a very tremendous success as well. The report identifies the various volunteers that were involved. So not only in relation to operating the food banks, but also in relation to, let's say things like the community health shuttle services that we were providing.  We had three shuttles running in Te Amadu, Cambridge and Te Kauwhiti to help the most vulnerable people in our communities get the various medical assistance or whatever welfare requirements they needed at the time. So I think our welfare committees work pretty well in our towns. So just in the summary, collaboration between the Western Waikato EEOC,  the direct input of our Iwi connections into the EOC through the Zoom meetings, making sure that we delivered the wealthier requirements as we needed to our most vulnerable communities worked really well. So tremendous thanks to our volunteers that helped the EOC. I think the relationships as we move forward are going to be much stronger, particularly  particularly with the iwi's connections there, that we have key people that we can go to with future EOC emergencies. The de-escalation has occurred through the various levels. So the Western Waikato EOC was disestablished on the 14th of May, and essentially four EOCs became to two EOCs. There's a Northern EOC, which represented pretty much Waikato District, Hamilton,  and the Southern EOC, which was our area representing our Western Waikato councils, Taupo and South Waikato. Now it's based in Taupo district, coordinated by Dave Symes, who was our EOC, sorry, local controller. So that Southern EOC is now just also being disestablished yesterday, 2nd of June. So with the rejection and the 800 number calls that are coming through,  the services will go back to MSD. But importantly, for ongoing support, for those that want to remain as food bank providers, we'll be getting some more information now from the Civil Defence Group to our key people, including our iwi liaison, about applications to MSD which have to be in by the 8th of June to carry on as a food bank provider and ongoing support by MSD in that area.  We will be seeking to recover our costs for the welfare requirements through government, so we're just working through that process now, not anticipating any difficulties because all of our costs essentially have been for welfare requirements for our communities and people. So that's it, Your Worship and the committee. That's essentially the update at the moment. As I say, it's still an ongoing  a matter for support through our group, but it is, we are transitioning out from, in terms of emergency management, transitioning out of the response and moving more into a recovery phase associated with the COVID-19 requirements. So we worship the reporters that the recommendation, the report be received. That's it for me.
